newsitem.title: UK: UK's Labour rejects talk of income tax rift.
newsitem.headline: UK's Labour rejects talk of income tax rift.

text.p: The UK opposition Labour Party on Tuesday rejected a suggestion of a rift between leader Tony Blair and economic spokesman Gordon Brown on the future level of income tax rates.

Asked at a news conference whether the reason Labour had not yet said whether it planned a 50 pence in the pound income tax band for very high earners, Labour shadow chief secretary to the Treasury Alistair Darling said, "You will get it when we judge the time is appropriate."
Labour deputy leader John Prescott said of the suggestion of a rift, "It is absolute rubbish."
Darling added, "We have made it repeatedly clear that we will set out any proposals for change (in tax) prior to the election."
There have been reports that Brown is resisting suggestions from other senior Labour politicians for a 50 pence tax band on earnings above 100,000 stg a year.
